rows.title: Meditation

transcript.eng:
Today's pause is called loving kindness meditation.
Find a comfortable sitting position, your feet flat on the floor, your hands resting in your lap.
Close your eyes if you are comfortable, or maintain a soft gaze. 
Ask yourself, “What is my experience in this moment?” 
Notice what thoughts you are experiencing. 
Notice how you feel emotionally. 
Notice how your body feels. Notice any discomfort or tension.
Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. 
You can then say the following words silently to yourself: 
May I be peaceful. 
May I be safe. 
May I be healthy. 
May I be happy. 
May I feel loved. 
Repeat slowly once or twice, taking your time between each phrase.
If you feel comfortable, you can also send thoughts of loving-kindness to your child, your partner, your family, and anyone else who is close to you in your life.
Now, allow your focus to expand to the whole body. 
Allow your focus to expand to the sounds in the room. 
Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. 
Open your eyes, and when you are ready, continue to your lesson with a sense of calm. 
Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us.

rows.text_1:
Today's topic is about helping your child learn and grow. 

Playing with your child is important for their growth and learning, both in and out of school. This is true for all children, including those with disabilities.

Did you know that playing helps your child learn what is expected and how to get along with others?

Children learn a lot by asking questions. Support their interests and curiosity, and be patient when they make mistakes. We all learn from our mistakes!
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Hello!
Do you know that children learn best through playing? 
And let’s be honest, which child does not like to play? 
Learning takes time, but there is a lot that you can do as a parent to help your child. Let them play and explore. Let them ask questions and learn from mistakes. And be patient. Your support will help them grow and develop.

rows.text_1:
Children learn best by playing and doing. 

@data.characters.f3_mother.name wants to spend more time helping her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, learn through play together. Let’s see how she does it.

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f3_mother.name: Hi, my love. Would you like to do something fun together? 

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name: Ooooh yes!

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name: First, we hang one bed sheet from the top bunk bed. It’s our first wall! Then, we can use a pillow at the bottom.

@data.characters.f3_mother.name: It's lovely to see you thinking everything through so carefully.

rows.text_1: @data.characters.f3_mother.name helped her son learn by playing together. Let’s explore how she did this.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Yes, by self-directing, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learned how to give clear instructions and lead an activity. This is an important skill for any successful adult!There are other correct answers in this list. Did you find them all?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2:
That’s right! By creatively imagining what a home could be, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name finds an innovative way to repurpose a bed sheet. In his imagination, he could be building a castle, bear den, or space shuttle. Innovation and creativity are critical skills for the future. 

This isn’t the only thing @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learned! Did you find the other things he learned?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That’s it! By imagining a world with a tent that doesn’t yet exist, and creatively solving a challenge, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name is learning critical skills for academic and professional success. There are more right answers in this list. Did you find them?
rows.quiz_1_question: What did @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn when his mother played with him?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: How to lead and give instructions
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: How to imagine new possibilities & problem solve
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4:
That’s right! By testing and trying materials to build a fort, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name is learning critical STEM skills and the parts of 3-dimensional shapes. 

There is more than one answer in this list! Did you find them all?
rows.quiz_2_question: How did @data.characters.f3_mother.name  help her son learn these skills?  There are lots of right answers to this one!
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Exactly! Their play time together had so many opportunities to learn new skills.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Actually, by simply playing with her son and letting him lead the activity, @data.characters.f3_mother.name helps her son learn. She doesn’t have to show him how to build a fort, he learns on his own with natural consequences.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Exactly! When @data.characters.f3_mother.name lets her son lead, she allows him to explore the laws of gravity (will the sheet fall?), 3-dimensional shapes, and build communication skills.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4: That’s right. When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son, he learns that it is good to be curious, inventive, and attentive to detail. He is more likely to repeat these behaviours in the future because he has been praised for them.

rows.text_1:
Children (just like us) can learn a lot from their mistakes.

Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name supports @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name to learn from her mistake when she plays a bit too rough indoors.

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f3_uncle.name: “@data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, please walk slowly in the house! You’re going to break something.” 

 @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name: “No I won’t!”
*@data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name runs into a table and breaks a vase. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name sees and is concerned.*

@data.characters.f3_uncle.name: “Are you hurt??”

 @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name: “No, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name. I’m so, so sorry for breaking the vase… I didn’t see it.”

@data.characters.f3_uncle.name: “I am not happy that you broke the vase but appreciate you for realising your mistake and apologising. Do you know how you could have prevented that from happening?”

 @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name: “Yes, I should have listened. I continued running even after you asked me to walk in the house.”

@data.characters.f3_uncle.name: “It’s OK, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name. I’m proud that you are able to learn from your mistakes. Let’s get a broom to sweep up the pieces. We may be able to repair the vase with some glue.”

 @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name: “Okay…”

rows.text_1: Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name helped @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name learn from her mistake!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Yes, he warns her in order to avoid the mistake.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Yes, when your child makes a mistake it is important to stay calm.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Yes, when the accident happens, he first asks if @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name is okay!
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: He gives an instruction to prevent the mistake
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: He shows he cares most about @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: He thanks @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name for recognising her mistake
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Yes, praise helps our children to take more responsibility for their actions next time.
rows.quiz_2_option_1_text: It is okay to make mistakes
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Exactly! @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name learns important things because @data.characters.f3_uncle.name responds in a calm and supportive way.

rows.section_1_text:
Play is the main way children learn and develop. Through play, they build important physical and social skills. 

Set aside time to play games with your child, be creative, and have fun together.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Through play, you also learn what kind of support your child may need.
Support your child to play and make friends with other children, so they learn how to interact with others well. 

If your child starts to feel overwhelmed with anything in their day, help them reduce their stress by taking a pause and playing together.
rows.section_2_text:
Learning new things takes time. Be patient and encourage your child to keep trying things they may find hard. 

Stay calm when they get angry or frustrated - your child will learn to do the same over time.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
You can support them by praising them for trying and helping them break large tasks into smaller tasks appropriate for their age.

Use play to help your child learn difficult skills, like losing, sharing, or taking turns.
rows.section_3_text:
Children learn by asking questions and exploring the things they are interested in. Give your child time and space to do this. 

Join your child’s activities and ask them questions to encourage them to learn more.
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Your child may talk a lot and have many questions - including difficult ones. You can give your child short but honest answers. 

If you need a break or more information, you can take a pause and tell your child you will respond to them later.

rows.text_1:
Want to help your child develop and grow?

Invite your child to play with you today. Encourage them to ask questions and explore new things through play.
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
I thought that my daughter only started learning when she went to school. 

@global.app_name gave me lots of ideas for what I could do to help her develop at home. By playing together, we were able to practise many words in a fun way. She is speaking much more now, and we are closer because of the time we spend together.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That’s right! Join in on any play activity your child is doing. You will strengthen your bond and encourage your child to play and learn more.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Great idea. Try to look for opportunities to play and learn, like balancing over a ridge or collecting leaves or rocks along the way.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Yes! Get creative. Anything in your home could be a music instrument, costume, or item in a role-play.
rows.quiz_1_question: What could you do today to encourage your child to play and learn?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Exactly. If you are not sure how you could play together, your child will have many ideas for what you could do.
